choices.C: Verify the SSID with which the device is associated
choices.B: Check the data usage statistics on the device
choices.D: Run any pending application or OS updates

questions.question_text:
A user's smartphone is experiencing limited bandwidth when at home. The user reports to a technician that the device functions properly when at work or in the car.
Which of the following troubleshooting steps should the technician take NEXT?

discussion.content: The answer should be "A"
Guys try to use the elimination technique here. Rest of the answers are cannot be correct

comments.content: man, read the question carefully, it said" device functions properly when at work or in the car"

discussion.content: I think we can assume that he is using data cause the question mentioned that he even has this issue "when work or in the car". Basically when cant use WIFI in the car cause is in roaming. Considering this I guess here can be best asnwer reset device's setting.

comments.content:
this explanation is from Jason Dion, if you don't believe me lol
Explanation
OBJ-3.5: Most likely, Nicole's smartphone is connecting to a neighbor's wireless network instead of her own. This network likely has a lower signal strength since it is outside her home, and this is causing the limited or slow bandwidth. Therefore, you should first verify that Nicole is connected to the proper wireless network before conducting any additional troubleshooting.

It doesn't Specifically mention Wi-Fi, however the central issue of this questions is "limited bandwidth" which is why verifying the SSID is the answer. The Trick to this question is that, the question fronts loads the meaningful information but emphases the second sentence. You really have to read the whole question to get it right. 
note: I did not get it right the first time.

it doesen't mention Wifi, but it's what makes the most sense.
The common reasons why a smartphone would work in some
places and not at home would be bad signal at home and good
signal out, or there's an issue with the Wifi. None of the
answers mention the phone is using data, so we must assume
it's using wifi instead. No other answer would explain the
cellphone's behaviour.
It's likely the smartphone is connected to another SSID whose
signal is too far away from the user.

discussion.content: This question mentions nothing about Wi-Fi

questions.question_text:
A company's security policy does not allow USB drives to be available in workstations. However, an exception needs to be made for a user. The network administrator changes the policy for the user.
Which of the following commands should the administrator run on the user's workstation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct, I normally use /force with it

This is an example of how you need to think through scenarios and break it down. 
Answer B has already been done
Answer C is the job of law enforcement, not you
Answer D seems like the right answer but the scenarios already sait that's been done
Answer A is the only answer that remains even though it's fulfilled by locking the computer away. But since that is the last recommended step then you choose this answer.

comments.content: The integrity of the data is not just in its physical safety, but in the chain of custody which is the preservation of evidence. This documents who had custody of the evidence as the events unfolded.
Having said that, I think Answer A actually should read "maintain chain of custody" as I have seen a similar question with Dion & Messer where the emphasis is to maintain the chain of custody.

Its not about calling the police. It is about reporting this entire scenario, now, to company management. They do not know any of this has happened yet.

When a legal violation is found, we are expected to comply with the law, so we do not ask permission from management to obey the legal requirements for our profession. The police are automatically called (in a fully ethical scenario, which CompTIA assumes), and then company management would begin getting phone calls about what has transpired, etc.

Again, this is CompTIA we are talking about here. I doubt it would go dxown this was in most cases, but this is what expected in a fully "Pure-hearted capitalistic enterprise" so to speak *shrug*

The integrity of data is not just in the physical isolation according to Comptia objectives "Chain of Custody" This is the chronological documentation or paper trail of evidence.
It should be initiated at the start of any investigation. It documents who had
custody of the evidence all the way up to litigation (if necessary), and logs the
transfer of evidence from person to person. It also verifies that the evidence
has not been modified or tampered with.

Common sense would dictate that if a computer has been locked & isolated securely that the data has been preserved and A is a non-answer. Process of elimination based on what the question actually says (not presumes) is D.
Well if they say that it will stay there until the local authorities arrive I would assume they already called so now we are waiting for them ? Just common sense

where do they say that it has been reported through the proper channels?
All they have done is removed the computer and put it in
a locker, they're letting us know the computer will stay there
until the local authorities arrive, they never said they
called them. That's what you need to do next and that's why
the correct answer is D. Report through proper channels

discussion.content:
A. Preserve data integrity
B. Identify violations of acceptable use
C. Collect evidence of illegal activity
D. Report through proper channels

B and C, do not make any sense in this question. We can scratch these. 
A and D, do make sense. 

A. Preserve data integrity - DIGITAL INFO is susceptible to tampering, access to the evidence must be controlled. Since the computer has already been put inside a cypher-lock room (security control), this means that the "Data is being preserved", thus we can scratch this answer. 

D. Report through proper channels - The question also implies that we are waiting for the local authorities. BUT, this also implies on Chain of Custody, which is vital that the evidence collected at the crime scene conform to a valid timeline.
A Chain of Custody form records where, when, and who collected the evidence, who has handled it, and where it was stored. Regardless if the authorities were called, there needs to be a "Report through the proper channels" still to be completed aka Chain of Custody form.

comments.content: The correct answer is D.
NO eldaulo, no it is not
hisfave is right, if you read the quest, youll see the report has already been made and police are on their way...

You do actually seem to suggest that they might have already suggested an on-going process to the data preservation, but perhaps the response they want for the question is to really emphasise (potentially again) that on-going part of the process with the response.

Correct answer is A: Chain of Custody is the chronological documentation or paper trail of evidence. This is what preservers the Integrity of the data (Not the literal physical securing of data) but the paper trail.

I do hopefully get what your saying in a lot of ways and I did originally thought it might be D. but the response could be A. because although there have been initial efforts and operations to preserve the data, there is still more they might need to do later on to preserve the data, as data preservation can be an on-going process rather that a once only type procedure in some cases.

"Since the computer has already been put inside a cypher-lock room (security control), this means that the "Data is being preserved", thus we can scratch this answer." ROOKIE - The preservation of data integrity IS IN the chain of custody! Which IS the chronological documentation or paper trail of evidence! Data INTEGRITY!

discussion.content: Tricky answers!

"A" may be the correct answer..."D" will only matter if this is just a tech who worked on it. But it says IT Department in which it has already been reported to the tech's supervisor or manager. IT Department will only proceed with next step once they got approval from the management, so preserving the data's integrity would likely be the next step

"The IT department has removed the computer and placed it in a secured, cypher-locked room, where it will remain until the local authorities arrive." Can someone explain how this isn't preserving data integrity? Isn't exactly what's being done here??

Difficult to know if (A) or (D), but "Report through proper channels" could equally mean reporting the offending user through proper channels such as their manager and human resources, where they'll be dealt with according to AUP and potentially terminated, etc.

Just wow on this question its all over the place, but it seems as though even in the step process they skipped preserving data and technically calling the police. but since its in a secure location meaning isolated not backed up especially temp files. And states authorities are on their way so they only have one thing to do that is preserve data. hopefully no one see this question on the test.
A, all answers have already been done. Preserving data means to: validate data, backup data, remove duplicate data, access control, and keeping a audit trail( or chain of custody)

This is REAL simple: The computer with illegal data has been secured and preserved, period. IT will not provide access to anyone except the authorities, so A has been DONE. B is DONE. As noted, cops will do C. IT needs to notify via the appropriate channels OUTSIDE of IT like Legal, HR, and the affected chain. Answer is D. Don't let these wrongly suggested answers by whomever (not CompTIA) mislead you or question your common sense.

comments.content:
Not so fast ROOKIE Correct answer is A: 

Chain of Custody is the chronological documentation or paper trail of evidence. This is what preservers the Integrity of the data (Not the literal physical securing of data) but the paper trail.

discussion.content:
The answer fully is:
Preserve data integrity, eliminate data redundancy, limited data view

for me its A since the word "IT department" so meaning the user is already reported to the PROPER CHANNEL which is the IT Department lets say they are just like IT assistant to the admin but still they function the precautions like securing the data integrity till the IT admin will come. why do you wait for the person if you have the rights to do it right away

To me the only job of the IT department is A. C is clearly law enforcement but B and D are often the responsibility of the organization's leaders in connection with HR or other entities within the organization. Seems to me that A is the only responsibility that clearly rests with IT.

comments.content: you are correct. The right answer is D
NO betty_boop, the correct answer is A

Betty in this rare case you are actually wrong. It has clearly already been reported as the police are already on their way. This is ALL about the A+ objective CHAIN OF CUSTODY which is the securing of the PAPER TRAIL of evidence to keep the INTEGRITY of the data.

discussion.content: The question says "where it will remain until the local authorities arrive." but it does not mention that the incident already reported what do you say about option "D"

Yes A it is because whatever happens in this case protecting the data at all cost is a must. Even if they have locked the system away they have to make sure the data is protected. Remember that someone can remotely wipe the data

questions.question_text:
A user's computer is suspected of hosting illegal files. The IT department has removed the computer and placed it in a secured, cypher-locked room, where it will remain until the local authorities arrive.
Which of the following actions should the IT department perform NEXT?
Which of the following would a technician use to store memory chips from a laptop safely after an upgrade?

discussion.content:
Antistatic containers is the most correct answer. Antistatic containers, typically bags, are made of or are lined with polyethylene terephthalate (PET).
Mylar is incorrect. Mylar is a brand name for biaxally-oriented polyethylene terephthalate (BoPET) which is noted for its electrical insulation properties and can be very shiny. The molecule chains are different, and is not used for antistatic containers.
Cardboard boxes are incorrect; cardboard does not shield well from electrical damage or water damage.
Paper envelopes is incorrect; this container affords the least possible protection of all choices, leaving components vulnerable to electrical, magnetic, and physical dangers.

comments.content: The "infected device" is the mail server -- the question says "the email originated from the corporate email server" -- NOT from Joe's computer.
No. It is pushed from the user device to the mail server using SMTP. This is basic stuff that you really should not be getting wrong by the 2nd exam.
When you write an email in your computer, the email is actually originated (sent) from the email server.

discussion.content: Security is everything in a company, you have to separate the infected device and clean it first before making other changes.

comments.content: its says after ruling out spoofing.

You have to follow the A+ steps to troubleshoot malware, this is what the exam is about.... The 2nd step is to Isolate the computer..... remediating the system comes after this.. And if you only change the password that is stupid because you left the malware infection. ROOKIE mistake.
Agreed, typical CompTIA world answer that isn't true in the real world. I googled this same question on 4 other exam prep sites and they all list D as the answer.
Because they all copy and paste from each other with no verification, the answer is not provided by CompTIA and is not necessarily correct.
Actually the second step according to CompTIA when you suspect malware is to Isolate the system so the answer is D.

discussion.content:
B. Change the password on Joe's email account – that will stop hackers from successfully accessing Joe’s account
Not D -- The Question says " the technician verifies the email originated from the corporate email server” – that means that the email did not originate from Joe’s computer. So why isolate Joe’s computer if the emails are not originating from it?

7 Steps/Best Practices of Malware Removal. Based on these steps, the first action the technician should take is D. Isolate Joe’s computer from the network. This aligns with Step 2: “Quarantine infected systems”. Isolating the computer would help prevent any potential malware from spreading to other systems on the network. After the system has been isolated, the technician can proceed with the other steps such as remediation and updating the antivirus software.

If the email was compromised which is the case here, the hacker will definitely try or have tried to infect other computers by compromising Joe email account.
In such a case it will make sense to remove the user’s computer from the network immediately and start scanning for any potential malware removal.

many are discussing about malware steps but the situation says Joe after ruling out spoofing meaning it's not a malware but someone hack his password. Am i and the few of us makes sense or were wrong?

the technician verifies the email originated from the corporate email server. I think this is the key phrase. IF let's say Joe's email account was not a corporate account, but a Gmail, or hotmail account, you would change the password. Remember, this says FIRST step. D and A will not prevent further emails from being sent from the email server. Corporate or not.

Hey Guys understand one thing, yeah it originated from server but remember Joe computer spread to others, best action first is to isolate joe computer from infecting more others , remember , steps of virus action.

B is the only answer that makes sense. A threat used Joe's credentials to directly access his mailbox on the server and send emails.
The emails did not originate from his PC so no sense in isolating or scanning it.

comments.content: The answer would definitely be C if it was applied to the server and not his PC.
It says what is the FIRST thing you would do. Isolating the PC would come before anything if it was infected.

That is what you want to do eventually. The problem is if the computer is infected there's no point changing the password until you've dealt with the infection, as the new password will just be grabbed in the same way they got the old one. First thing you will have to do is remove the infection. The first step CompTIA expects when dealing with an infected machine is to isolate it so it can't spread elsewhere, you don;t want to download updates to the antivirus directly from this machine either because you don't know if malware is interefering with the download and preventing the update performing properly.

Why do ppl bring up spoofing, spoofing means the emailed "looked" like it came from Joe but it actually didn't, technician verified and ruled out the spoofing meaning the email was actually sent by "joe"
even though Joe said after ruling out spoofing?

You are right.
Let's think a bit harder. The suspicious email is from Joe’s email, but not coming from his device/ computer. The email originated from the corporate (company email server). Meaning Joe’s account was hacked and used on the user. Does the question say What are the first steps are? Changing and resetting Joe's password, the server, or Joe’s computer can be the next steps t. Resetting Joe’s password will disconnect the hacker’s access.
if someone has Joe's password how did they get it? Either he gave it to someone (or someone watched him put it in) or he has a Key Logger Isolate his system THEN change his password
I agree, this is email hijacking... the same question is in Dion's or in Meyers.

discussion.content: B. Change Joe's password - the question says it's "not spoofing" -- so somebody else is using Joe's credentials - change his password.

questions.question_text:
Joe, a user, reports that several of his colleagues have received a suspicious email from his account that he did not send. A technician asks one of the colleagues to forward the email for inspection. After ruling out spoofing, the technician verifies the email originated from the corporate email server.
Which of the following is the FIRST step the technician should take to correct this issue?

choices.D: Isolate Joe's computer from the network
choices.A: See if Joe's email address has been blacklisted
choices.B: Change the password on Joe's email account
choices.C: Update the antivirus and perform a full scan on the PC
